item.title: 23andMe files for bankruptcy, customers advised to delete DNA data
item.author: Sergiu Gatlan
item.content:encoded: ​California-based genetic testing provider 23andMe has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and plans to sell its assets following years of financial struggles. [...]

item.title: New VanHelsing ransomware targets Windows, ARM, ESXi systems
item.author: Bill Toulas
item.content:encoded: A new multi-platform ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation named VanHelsing has emerged, targeting Windows, Linux, BSD, ARM, and ESXi systems. [...]

item.title: Critical Ingress NGINX Controller Vulnerability Allows RCE Without Authentication
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: A set of five critical security shortcomings have been disclosed in the Ingress NGINX Controller for Kubernetes that could result in unauthenticated remote code execution, putting over 6,500 clusters at immediate risk by exposing the component to the public internet. The vulnerabilities (CVE-2025-24513, CVE-2025-24514, CVE-2025-1097, CVE-2025-1098, and CVE-2025-1974 ), assigned a CVSS score of

item.title: Cyberattack takes down Ukrainian state railway’s online services
item.author: Bill Toulas
item.content:encoded: Ukrzaliznytsia, Ukraine's national railway operator, has been hit by a massive cyberattack that disrupted online services for buying tickets both through mobile apps and the website. [...]

item.title: DrayTek routers worldwide go into reboot loops over weekend
item.author: Sergiu Gatlan
item.content:encoded: Many Internet service providers (ISPs) worldwide are alerting customers of an outage that started Saturday night and triggered DrayTek router connectivity problems. [...]

item.title: Chinese Weaver Ant hackers spied on telco network for 4 years
item.author: Bill Toulas
item.content:encoded: A China-linked advanced threat group named Weaver Ant spent more than four years in the network of a telecommunications services provider, hiding traffic and infrastructure with the help of compromised Zyxel CPE routers. [...]

item.title: Microsoft Adds Inline Data Protection to Edge for Business to Block GenAI Data Leaks
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: Microsoft on Monday announced a new feature called inline data protection for its enterprise-focused Edge for Business web browser. The native data security control is designed to prevent employees from sharing sensitive company-related data into consumer generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) apps like OpenAI ChatGPT, Google Gemini, and DeepSeek. The list will be expanded over time to

item.title: Police arrests 300 suspects linked to African cybercrime rings
item.author: Sergiu Gatlan
item.content:encoded: African law enforcement authorities have arrested 306 suspects as part of 'Operation Red Card,' an INTERPOL-led international crackdown targeting cross-border cybercriminal networks. [...]

item.title: Critical flaw in Next.js lets hackers bypass authorization
item.author: Bill Toulas
item.content:encoded: A critical severity vulnerability has been discovered in the Next.js open-source web development framework, potentially allowing attackers to bypass authorization checks. [...]

item.title: VanHelsing RaaS Launch: 3 Victims, $5K Entry Fee, Multi-OS, and Double Extortion Tactics
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: A ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation called VanHelsing has already claimed three victims since it launched on March 7, 2025. "The RaaS model allows a wide range of participants, from experienced hackers to newcomers, to get involved with a $5,000 deposit. Affiliates keep 80% of the ransom payments, while the core operators earn 20%," Check Point said in a report published over the weekend

item.title: Hidden Threats: How Microsoft 365 Backups Store Risks for Future Attacks
item.author: Sponsored by Acronis
item.content:encoded: Acronis Threat Research found 2M+ malicious URLs & 5,000+ malware instances in Microsoft 365 backup data—demonstrating how built-in security isn't always enough. Don't let threats persist in your cloud data. Strengthen your defenses. [...]

item.title: ⚡ THN Weekly Recap: GitHub Supply Chain Attack, AI Malware, BYOVD Tactics, and More
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: A quiet tweak in a popular open-source tool opened the door to a supply chain breach—what started as a targeted attack quickly spiraled, exposing secrets across countless projects. That wasn’t the only stealth move. A new all-in-one malware is silently stealing passwords, crypto, and control—while hiding in plain sight. And over 300 Android apps joined the chaos, running ad fraud at scale behind

item.title: VSCode Marketplace Removes Two Extensions Deploying Early-Stage Ransomware
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: Cybersecurity researchers have uncovered two malicious extensions in the Visual Studio Code (VSCode) Marketplace that are designed to deploy ransomware that's under development to its users. The extensions, named "ahban.shiba" and "ahban.cychelloworld," have since been taken down by the marketplace maintainers. Both the extensions, per ReversingLabs, incorporate code that's designed to invoke a

item.title: How to Balance Password Security Against User Experience
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: If given the choice, most users are likely to favor a seamless experience over complex security measures, as they don’t prioritize strong password security. However, balancing security and usability doesn’t have to be a zero-sum game. By implementing the right best practices and tools, you can strike a balance between robust password security and a frictionless user experience (UX). This article

item.title: More Countries are Demanding Back-Doors to Encrypted Apps
item.author: Bruce Schneier
item.content:encoded: Last month I wrote about the UK forcing Apple to break its Advanced Data Protection encryption in iCloud. More recently, both Sweden and France are contemplating mandating back doors. Both initiatives are attempting to scare people into supporting back doors, which are—of course—are terrible idea.

item.title: Critical Next.js Vulnerability Allows Attackers to Bypass Middleware Authorization Checks
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: A critical security flaw has been disclosed in the Next.js React framework that could be potentially exploited to bypass authorization checks under certain conditions. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-29927, carries a CVSS score of 9.1 out of 10.0. "Next.js uses an internal header x-middleware-subrequest to prevent recursive requests from triggering infinite loops," Next.js said in an

item.title: Google Gemini's Astra (screen sharing) rolls out on Android for some users
item.author: Mayank Parmar
item.content:encoded: At MWC 2025, Google confirmed it was working on screen and video share capabilities for Gemini Live, codenamed "Project Astra". At that time, Google promised that the feature would begin rolling out soon, and now some users have spotted it in the wild. [...]

item.title: FBI warnings are true—fake file converters do push malware
item.author: Lawrence Abrams
item.content:encoded: The FBI is warning that fake online document converters are being used to steal people's information and, in worst-case scenarios, lead to ransomware attacks. [...]

item.title: Coinbase Initially Targeted in GitHub Actions Supply Chain Attack; 218 Repositories' CI/CD Secrets Exposed
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: The supply chain attack involving the GitHub Action "tj-actions/changed-files" started as a highly-targeted attack against one of Coinbase's open-source projects, before evolving into something more widespread in scope. "The payload was focused on exploiting the public CI/CD flow of one of their open source projects – agentkit, probably with the purpose of leveraging it for further compromises,"

item.title: Cloudflare now blocks all unencrypted traffic to its API endpoints
item.author: Bill Toulas
item.content:encoded: Cloudflare announced that it closed all HTTP connections and it is now accepting only secure, HTTPS connections for api.cloudflare.com. [...]

item.title: Microsoft Trust Signing service abused to code-sign malware
item.author: Lawrence Abrams
item.content:encoded: Cybercriminals are abusing Microsoft's Trusted Signing platform to code-sign malware executables with short-lived three-day certificates. [...]

item.title: Microsoft Trusted Signing service abused to code-sign malware
item.author: Lawrence Abrams
item.content:encoded: Cybercriminals are abusing Microsoft's Trusted Signing platform to code-sign malware executables with short-lived three-day certificates. [...]

item.title: U.S. Treasury Lifts Tornado Cash Sanctions Amid North Korea Money Laundering Probe
item.author: The Hacker News
item.content:encoded: The U.S. Treasury Department has announced that it's removing sanctions against Tornado Cash, a cryptocurrency mixer service that has been accused of aiding the North Korea-linked Lazarus Group to launder their ill-gotten proceeds. "Based on the Administration's review of the novel legal and policy issues raised by use of financial sanctions against financial and commercial activity occurring

item.title: Coinbase was primary target of recent GitHub Actions breaches
item.author: Lawrence Abrams
item.content:encoded: Researchers have determined that Coinbase was the primary target in a recent GitHub Actions cascading supply chain attack that compromised secrets in hundreds of repositories. [...]
